title: Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM)
text:
History of watery vaginal discharge.
Sterile speculum examination demonstrating liquor.
The role of ultrasound assessment of amniotic fluid volume is unclear.
Digital vaginal exam should not be done unless in labor.

title: Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM)
text:
History of watery vaginal discharge.
Sterile speculum examination demonstrating liquor.
The role of ultrasound assessment of amniotic fluid volume is unclear.
Digital vaginal exam should not be done unless in labor.

title: Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM)
text:
Management

Admission. Outpatient management only by consultant decision (individualized).
Antibiotics:

Penicillin
Azithromycin

Antenatal corticosteroids if <34/<36 weeks (dexamethasone, after screening for GDM):

6 mg IM q12h x 4 doses, or
12 mg IM q24h x 2 doses

Magnesium sulfate for neuroprotection if <30/<34 weeks
Neonatologists should be informed when delivery is anticipated

title: Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM)
text:
Special considerations

Previable ROM

<20 weeks → counsel regarding poor prognosis; risk of pulmonary hypoplasia, skeletal deformities, and neonatal death, in addition to risk of maternal morbidity from chorioamnionitis and sepsis.
20-<24 weeks → expectant management or termination of pregnancy after counseling.
24 weeks → expectant management.



Women with cerclage





Preterm labor

Tocolysis:



Chorioamnionitis

A combination of clinical assessment, maternal blood tests (CRP and WBC) and FHR should be used to diagnose chorioamnionitis in women with PPROM; these parameters should not be used in isolation
Diagnosis:

Maternal fever >38°C plus 2 of the following:

Maternal tachycardia >100 bpm
Fetal tachycardia >160 bpm
Uterine tenderness
Foul smelling vaginal discharge
Elevated WBC >15,000/mm3 (less reliable if corticosteroids given)


Management:

title: Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM)
text:
Postpartum/preconceptional advice

Risk in subsequent pregnancies is increased

title: About this site
text: This website provides management protocols for clinical practice at Ain Shams University Women’s Hospital. These protocols serve as evidence-based reference guides for healthcare professionals working within our institution.

title: About this site
text:
How protocols were developed
Each protocol was developed through a comprehensive review of current international guidelines, including those from NICE, RCOG, ACOG, SOGC, FIGO, and WHO. Relevant recommendations were then adapted to align with the our real-world capabilities, resources, and patient population.

This is a Quarto website.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.

title: ASU-GO
text: Ain Shams University Gynecology & Obstetrics Protocols

title: About this site
text: This website provides management protocols for clinical practice at Ain Shams University Women’s Hospital. These protocols serve as evidence-based reference guides for healthcare professionals working within our institution.

title: About this site
text:
Development methodology
Each protocol was developed through a comprehensive review of current international guidelines from NICE, RCOG, ACOG, SOGC, FIGO, and WHO. Evidence-based recommendations have been adapted to reflect our institution’s capabilities, resources, and patient population characteristics.

title: About this site
text:
Important disclaimer
These protocols are intended to support clinical decision-making but are not exhaustive and should not replace individual clinical judgment. Healthcare professionals must consider each patient’s unique circumstances and consult relevant specialists when necessary.

This is a Quarto website. To learn more, visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.
